# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

None.

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df_cars)
    # Filter the data frame to only rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df_audis = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df_cars)
    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` with all values set to true
    df_audis[:audi_a4_type] = true
    return df_audis
end
```

This function uses the `filter` function from the DataFrames package to filter out only the rows where the manufacturer is "audi" and the model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". It then creates a new column named `audi_a4_type` with all values set to `true` using broadcasting.

To use this function, you would simply call it with your DataFrame:

```julia
df_result = audi_filter(your_df)
```

Remember to replace `your_df` with the actual DataFrame you want to filter and modify.
